title: Poor Charlie's Almanack
description: A collection of speeches and talks by Charlie Munger, Warren Buffett's business partner. A great primer on Munger's mental models and investing philosophy.

title: Ben Franklin's Autobiography
description: The autobiography is written in simple langauge. The book demonstrates Ben's thinking style. The self-improvement plan had the most impact on me.

title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
description: I initially dismissed this book because it seemed to encourage inauthentic behavior. Over time, I found it helpful to understand people better. It's quite useful to read and re-read every couple of years.

title: Never Split the Difference
description: This is the best book on negotiation I've read. If I had to sum up the book in one quip, negotiation is "The art of letting someone else have your way."

title: Red-Blooded Risk
description: It's not the easiest read, but there were several concepts that I found nowhere else. My favorite insight was in a truel (3 person duel), the person who is the best shot has the lowest chance of survival.

title: Fortune's Formula
description: The book is about the Kelly Criterion, a formula for determining the optimal size of a series of bets. This book exposed me to Claude Shannon, who is the father of information theory. A key insight is that you can go broke even when your expected value is positive.

title: The Lessons of History
description: History begins once we record it. Everything before that is prehistory. Will Durant traces civilization from ancient Egypt through to the 20th century.
quote: Only a fool would try to compress a hundred centuries into a hundred pages of hazardous conclusions. We proceed.
